abstract.text: Asynchronously requests permission to read a data type that requires per-object authorization (such as vision prescriptions).

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: The HealthKit store where you’re requesting authorization.
The data type you want to read. This type must be a type that requires per-object authorization.
An optional predicate that further restricts the objects of interest.
A value used to trigger the request. This value must be a
variable.
Any change to the variable triggers a request.
A block that the system calls after the request is complete. The system passes the result parameter.
Some samples require per-object authorization.
For these samples, people can select which ones your app can read on a sample-by-sample basis.
By default, your app can read any of the per-object authorization samples that it has saved to the HealthKit store;
however, you may not always have access to those samples. People can update the authorization status for any of these samples at any time.
Your app can begin by setting up the request in SwiftUI.

code: fatalError("*** An error occurred while requesting authentication: \(error) ***")

inlineContent.text: Next, query for any samples that it already has permission to read.

code: // Read the newest prescription from the HealthKit store.
guard let result = try await queryDescriptor.result(for: store).first else {
fatalError("*** An error occurred while reading the most recent vision prescriptions: \(error.localizedDescription) ***")

inlineContent.text: Based on the results, you can then decide whether you need to request authorization for additional samples.
Modify the trigger’s value to prompt someone to modify the samples your app has access to read.
Using the
method to request read access to any data types
that require per-object authorization fails with an
error.
When your app calls this method, HealthKit displays an authorization sheet
that asks for permission to read the samples that match the predicate and object type.
The person using your app can then select individual samples to share with your app.
The system always asks for permission, regardless of whether the user previously granted it.
People can individually enable each of the prescriptions.
After they respond, the system calls the callback handler on an arbitrary background queue.

SwiftUI-PageImage-card.png.alt: A black Swift logo on a swirly blue and purple background.

abstract.text: Declare the user interface and behavior for your app on every platform.
A type that represents part of your app’s user interface and provides
modifiers that you use to configure views.
Asynchronously requests permission to read a data type that requires per-object authorization (such as vision prescriptions).
Requests permission to read the specified HealthKit data types.
Requests permission to save and read the specified HealthKit data types.
Presents a preview of the workout contents as a modal sheet
A property wrapper type that can read and write a value managed by SwiftUI.
Requests permission to save and read the specified HealthKit data types.
The app passed an invalid argument to the HealthKit API.
The access point for all data managed by HealthKit.
An abstract superclass with subclasses that identify a specific type of data for the HealthKit store.
A definition of logical conditions for constraining a search for a fetch or for in-memory filtering.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A value type whose instances are either `true` or `false`.
The return type of functions that don’t explicitly specify a return type, that is, an empty tuple `()`.
A type representing an error value that can be thrown.
A value that represents either a success or a failure, including an associated value in each case.
